introduction.p: We know that a linear system A\xvec=\bvec is inconsistent when \bvec is not in \col(A), the column space of A. Later in this chapter, we'll develop a strategy for dealing with inconsistent systems by finding \bhat, the vector in \col(A) that minimizes the distance to \bvec. The equation A\xvec=\bhat is therefore consistent and its solution set can provide us with useful information about the original system A\xvec=\bvec.
In this section and the next, we'll develop some techniques that enable us to find \bhat, the vector in a given subspace W that is closest to a given vector \bvec.

\vvec\cdot(c_1\wvec_1+c_2\wvec_2) = c_1\vvec\cdot\wvec_1 + c_2\vvec\cdot\wvec_2\text{.}
We'll work with the basis of \real^2 formed by the vectors

introduction.p: We frequently ask to write a given vector as a linear combination of given basis vectors. In the past, we have done this by solving a linear system. The preview activity illustrates how this task can be simplified when the basis vectors are orthogonal to each other. We'll explore this and other uses of orthogonal bases in this section.

subsection.title: Orthogonal sets
subsection.p: The preview activity dealt with a basis of \real^2 formed by two orthogonal vectors. More generally, we will consider a set of orthogonal vectors, as described in the next definition.

statement.p: By an orthogonal set of vectors, we mean a set of nonzero vectors each of which is orthogonal to the others.

subsection.p:
Suppose that a vector \bvec is a linear combination of an orthogonal set of vectors \wvec_1,\wvec_2,\ldots,\wvec_n; that is, suppose that
c_1\wvec_1 + c_2\wvec_2 + \cdots + c_n\wvec_n = \bvec.
Just as in the preview activity, we can find the weight c_1 by dotting both sides with \wvec_1 and applying the distributive property of dot products:
(c_1\wvec_1 + c_2\wvec_2 + \cdots + c_n\wvec_n)\cdot\wvec_1 \amp = \bvec\cdot\wvec_1
c_1\wvec_1\cdot\wvec_1 + c_2\wvec_2\cdot\wvec_1 +\cdots + c_n\wvec_n\cdot\wvec_1 \amp = \bvec\cdot\wvec_1
c_1\wvec_1\cdot\wvec_1 \amp = \bvec\cdot\wvec_1
c_1 \amp = \frac{\bvec\cdot\wvec_1}{\wvec_1\cdot\wvec_1}\text{.}
Notice how the presence of an orthogonal set causes most of the terms in the sum to vanish. In the same way, we find that
c_i = \frac{\bvec\cdot\wvec_i}{\wvec_i\cdot\wvec_i}
so that
\bvec = \frac{\bvec\cdot\wvec_1}{\wvec_1\cdot\wvec_1}\wvec_1 + \frac{\bvec\cdot\wvec_2}{\wvec_2\cdot\wvec_2}\wvec_2 + \cdots + \frac{\bvec\cdot\wvec_n}{\wvec_n\cdot\wvec_n}\wvec_n\text{.}
We'll record this fact in the following proposition.

statement.p:
If a vector \bvec is a linear combination of an orthogonal set of vectors \wvec_1,\wvec_2,\ldots,\wvec_n, then
\bvec = \frac{\bvec\cdot\wvec_1}{\wvec_1\cdot\wvec_1}\wvec_1 + \frac{\bvec\cdot\wvec_2}{\wvec_2\cdot\wvec_2}\wvec_2 + \cdots + \frac{\bvec\cdot\wvec_n}{\wvec_n\cdot\wvec_n}\wvec_n\text{.}
An orthogonal set of vectors \wvec_1,\wvec_2,\ldots,\wvec_n is linearly independent.

subsection.p: If the vectors in an orthogonal set have dimension m, they form a linearly independent set in \real^m and are therefore a basis for the subspace W=\laspan{\wvec_1,\wvec_2,\ldots,\wvec_n}. If there are m vectors in the orthogonal set, they form a basis for \real^m.

subsection.p:
This activity introduces an important way of modifying an orthogonal set so that the vectors in the set have unit length. Recall that we may multiply any nonzero vector \wvec by a scalar so that the new vector has length 1. For instance, we know that if s is a positive scalar, then \len{s\wvec} = s\len{\wvec}. To obtain a vector \uvec having unit length, we want
\len{\uvec} = \len{s\wvec} = s\len{\wvec} = 1
so that s=1/\len{\wvec}. Therefore,
\uvec = \frac{1}{\len{\wvec}}\wvec
becomes a unit vector parallel to \wvec.
Orthogonal sets in which the vectors have unit length are called orthonormal and are especially convenient.

statement.p: An orthonormal set is an orthogonal set of vectors each of which has unit length.

subsection.p: The previous activity and example illustrate the next proposition.

statement.p: If the columns of the m\times n matrix Q form an orthonormal set, then Q^TQ = I_n, the n\times n identity matrix.

subsection.title: Orthogonal projections
subsection.p: We now turn to an important problem that will appear in many forms in the rest of our explorations. Suppose, as shown in , that we have a subspace W of \real^m and a vector \bvec that is not in that subspace. We would like to find the vector \bhat in W that is closest to \bvec, meaning the distance between \bhat and \bvec is as small as possible.

figure.caption: Given a plane in \real^3 and a vector \bvec not in the plane, we wish to find the vector \bhat in the plane that is closest to \bvec.

subsection.p: To get started, let's consider a simpler problem where we have a line L in \real^2, defined by the vector \wvec, and another vector \bvec that is not on the line, as shown on the left of . We wish to find \bhat, the vector on the line that is closest to \bvec, as illustrated in the right of .

figure.caption: Given a line L and a vector \bvec, we seek the vector \bhat on L that is closest to \bvec.

subsection.p:
To find \bhat, we require that \bvec-\bhat be orthogonal to L. For instance, if \yvec is another vector on the line, as shown in , then the Pythagorean theorem implies that
\len{\bvec-\yvec}^2 = |\bvec-\bhat|^2 + |\bhat-\yvec|^2
which means that \len{\bvec-\yvec}\geq|\bvec-\bhat|. Therefore, \bhat is closer to \bvec than any other vector on the line L.

figure.caption: The vector \bhat is closer to \bvec than \yvec because \bvec-\bhat is orthogonal to L.

statement.p: Given a vector \bvec in \real^m and a subspace W of \real^m, the orthogonal projection of \bvec onto W is the vector \bhat in W that is closest to \bvec. It is characterized by the property that \bvec-\bhat is orthogonal to W.

subsection.p: In all the cases considered in the activity, we are looking for \bhat, the vector in a subspace W closest to a vector \bvec, which is found by requiring that \bvec-\bhat be orthogonal to W. This means that (\bvec-\bhat)\cdot\wvec = 0 for any vector \wvec in W.

If we have an orthogonal basis \wvec_1,\wvec_2,\ldots,\wvec_n for W, then \bhat = c_1\wvec_1+c_w\wvec_2+\cdots+c_n\wvec_n. Therefore,
(\bvec-\bhat)\cdot\wvec_i \amp = 0
\bvec\cdot\wvec_i \amp = \bhat\cdot\wvec_i
\bvec\cdot\wvec_i \amp = (c_1\wvec_1+c_2\wvec_2+\cdots + c_n\wvec_n)\cdot\wvec_i
\bvec\cdot\wvec_i \amp = c_i\wvec_i\cdot\wvec_i
c_i \amp = \frac{\bvec\cdot\wvec_i}{\wvec_i\cdot\wvec_i}.
This leads to the projection formula:

statement.p:
If W is a subspace of \real^m having an orthogonal basis \wvec_1,\wvec_2,\ldots, \wvec_n and \bvec is a vector in \real^m, then the orthogonal projection of \bvec onto W is
\bhat= \frac{\bvec\cdot\wvec_1}{\wvec_1\cdot\wvec_1}~\wvec_1 + \frac{\bvec\cdot\wvec_2}{\wvec_2\cdot\wvec_2}~\wvec_2 + \cdots + \frac{\bvec\cdot\wvec_n}{\wvec_n\cdot\wvec_n}~\wvec_n\text{.}

subsection.p: This activity demonstrates one issue of note. We found \bhat, the orthogonal projection of \bvec onto W, by requiring that \bvec-\bhat be orthogonal to W. In other words, \bvec-\bhat is a vector in the orthogonal complement W^\perp, which we may denote \bvec^\perp. This explains the following proposition, which is illustrated in

statement.p:
If W is a subspace of \real^n with orthogonal complement W^\perp, then any n-dimensional vector \bvec can be uniquely written as
\bvec = \bhat + \bvec^\perp
where \bhat is in W and \bvec^\perp is in W^\perp. The vector \bhat is the orthogonal projection of \bvec onto W and \bvec^\perp is the orthogonal projection of \bvec onto W^\perp.

figure.caption: A vector \bvec along with \bhat, its orthogonal projection onto the line L, and \bvec^\perp, its orthogonal projection onto the orthogonal complement L^\perp.

subsection.p:
Let's summarize what we've found. If Q is a matrix whose columns \uvec_1, \uvec_2,\ldots,\uvec_n form an orthonormal set in \real^m, then
Q^TQ = I_n, the n\times n identity matrix, because this product computes the dot products between the columns of Q.
QQ^T is the matrix the projects vectors orthogonally onto W, the subspace of \real^m spanned by \uvec_1,\ldots,\uvec_n.
As we've said before, matrix multiplication depends on the order in which we multiply the matrices, and we see this clearly here.

Because Q^TQ=I, there is a temptation to say that Q is invertible. This is usually not the case, however. Remember that an invertible matrix must be a square matrix, and the matrix Q will only be square if n=m. In this case, there are m vectors in the orthonormal set so the subspace W spanned by the vectors \uvec_1,\uvec_2,\ldots,\uvec_m is \real^m. If \bvec is a vector in \real^m, then \bhat=QQ^T\bvec is the orthogonal projection of \bvec onto \real^m. In other words, QQ^T\bvec is the closest vector in \real^m to \bvec, and this closest vector must be \bvec itself. Therefore, QQ^T\bvec = \bvec, which means that QQ^T=I. In this case, Q is an invertible matrix.

statement.p:
Consider the orthonormal set of vectors
\uvec_1=\threevec{1/\sqrt{3}}{-1/\sqrt{3}}{1/\sqrt{3}}, \hspace{24pt} \uvec_2=\threevec{1/\sqrt{2}}{1/\sqrt{2}}0
and the matrix they define
Q = \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \\ -1/\sqrt{3} \amp 1/\sqrt{2} \\ 1/\sqrt{3} \amp 0 \\ \end{bmatrix}\text{.}
In this case, \uvec_1 and \uvec_2 span a plane, a 2-dimensional subspace of \real^3. We know that Q^TQ = I_2 and QQ^T projects vectors orthogonally onto the plane. However, Q is not a square matrix so it cannot be invertible.

Moreover, since Q^TQ = I, we see that Q^{-1} = Q^T so finding the inverse of Q is as simple as writing its transpose. Matrices with this property are very special and will play an important role in our upcoming work. We will therefore give them a special name.
A square m\times m matrix Q whose columns form an orthonormal basis for \real^m is called orthogonal.

subsection.p: This terminology can be a little confusing. We call a basis orthogonal if the basis vectors are orthogonal to one another. However, a matrix is orthogonal if the columns are orthogonal to one another and have unit length. It pays to keep this in mind when reading statements about orthogonal bases and orthogonal matrices. In the meantime, we record the following proposition.

statement.p: An orthogonal matrix Q is invertible and its inverse Q^{-1} = Q^T.

subsection.title: Summary
subsection.p:
This section introduced orthogonal sets and the projection formula that allows us to project vectors orthogonally onto a subspace.
Given an orthogonal set \wvec_1,\wvec_2,\ldots,\wvec_n that spans an n-dimensional subspace W of \real^m, the orthogonal projection of \bvec onto W is the vector in W closest to \bvec and may be written as
\bhat = \frac{\bvec\cdot\wvec_1}{\wvec_1\cdot\wvec_1}~\wvec_1 + \frac{\bvec\cdot\wvec_2}{\wvec_2\cdot\wvec_2}~\wvec_2 + \cdots + \frac{\bvec\cdot\wvec_n}{\wvec_n\cdot\wvec_n}~\wvec_n\text{.}
If \uvec_1,\uvec_2,\ldots,\uvec_n is an orthonormal basis of W and Q is the matrix whose columns are \uvec_i, then the matrix P=QQ^T projects vectors orthogonally onto W.
If the columns of Q form an orthonormal basis for an n-dimensional subspace of \real^m, then Q^TQ=I_n.
An orthogonal matrix Q is a square matrix whose columns form an orthonormal basis. In this case, QQ^T=Q^TQ = I so that Q^{-1} = Q^T.
